title.narrative: Assessment of Domestic Work in Dhaka

description.narrative:
Employed domestic work has a long history in Bangladesh, a history that continues to the present. While there are currently no accurate data on the number of domestic workers living and working in Dhaka, estimates show that it is an enormous section of the workforce. According to the Bangladesh Bureau of Statistics Labour Force Survey 2006 (LFS), 331,000 people 15 years and older were officially employed as domestic workers in Bangladesh and 420,000 children worked as domestic workers. Moreover, the survey estimated that there were, in actuality, approximately 2 million domestic workers in the country. Furthermore, domestic workers as individuals and as a group have been recognized as a disadvantaged, underprivileged and neglected section of society. The Asian Development Bank#s study, The Informal Sector and Informal Employment in Bangladesh 2010# clearly identified that the informal sector, to which domesticwork in Bangladesh belongs, serves as an important source of employment in Bangladesh with approximately 42 million of 54 million jobs in the country's labour market in 2010 held in the informal sector. While domestic workers in the country include men and women,adults and children, the bulk of the sector, 83%, are female.
Oxfam in Bangladesh is exploring the development of a project and proposal to work with domestic workers in Dhaka, Bangladesh. The vision of the project will be to introduce degrees of formality and protection to the industry while striving to have domestic work recognized as a decent profession in Bangladesh.
The proposed assessment will provide basic data that will feed into the project proposal that will be developed. While a rigorous and thorough baselinestudy will be included as a part of the monitoring, evaluation and research component of the proposal, this proposed assessment will provide a basic snapshot of domestic work in Dhaka, thus providing a starting point for future research and a project baseline study.

participating-org.narrative: The Unnayan Onneshan-The Innovators, a centre for research and action on development, is an independent non-profit registered Trust, which aims to contribute to innovation in development through research, advocacy, solidarity and action. The centre was established in August 2003 (and registered) by a group of university faculties and development professionals across Bangladesh to contribute to the search for solutions to endemic poverty, injustice, gender inequality an environmental degradation at the local, national and global levels. The Trust is known as Unnayan Onneshan in Bangla and again it was registered in 2008 (Registration No.5859-iv-23, Date 12.06.2008). The internal professional staff and external fellows are grouped into three research based and two function based operational units – Economic Policy, Social Policy, Climate Change, Biodiversity and DRR, Perspective Building and Policy Literacy Unit, and HR, Admin and Finance. The Unnayan Onneshan is a Progressive think- tank that undertakes research for advancing ideas and building constituencies for social transformation. The public- interest research institute works in collaboration with national partners, international organizations and leading universities.
